newsitem.title: USA: Trimedyne says product test is a success.
newsitem.headline: Trimedyne says product test is a success.

text.p: Trimedyne Inc on Monday said its 90-percent owned unit, Cardiodyne Inc, successfully completed animal tests of a transmyocardial revascularization process that creates lasered channels in dogs' hearts.

The company's procedure, called TMR, might eventually be used to treat patients with occluded arteries and angina. It could be a low cost alternative to balloon angioplasty and coronary bypass operations, Trimedyne said in a statement.

During TMR, a laser creates 20 to 50 channels through the heart wall into the left ventricle allowing oxygenated blood to permeate the left ventricular myocardium. The result is relief of anginal pain caused by oxygen deprivation.
Six weeks after the animal tests, examinations revealed vascular channels and new connecting vessels were created in dogs' hearts, Trimedyne said.
The procedures were performed at the Harbor UCLA Medical Center using Cardiodyne's proprietary Myocardial Revascularization System.

Cardiodyne will submit an application to the FDA to begin clinical trials of the Cardiodyne MR System, which consists of its proprietary SUPERPULSE Holmium Laser, AUTOFIRE Interface System and CHANNELMAKER Optical Fibers.
